Valid only if the policy type is StepScaling or SimpleScaling. For more information, see Scaling adjustment types in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Some Auto Scaling groups use instance weights. In this case, set the MinAdjustmentMagnitude to a value that is at least as large as your largest instance weight.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: predictiveScalingConfiguration
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
A predictive scaling policy. Provides support for predefined and custom metrics.

Predefined metrics include CPU utilization, network in/out, and the Application Load Balancer request count.

For more information, see PredictiveScalingConfiguration in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference.

Required if the policy type is PredictiveScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: scalingAdjustment
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
The amount by which to scale, based on the specified adjustment type. A positive value adds to the current capacity while a negative number removes from the current capacity. For exact capacity, you must specify a non-negative value.

Required if the policy type is SimpleScaling. (Not used with any other policy type.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: stepAdjustments
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
A set of adjustments that enable you to scale based on the size of the alarm breach.

Required if the policy type is StepScaling. (Not used with any other policy type.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: targetTrackingConfiguration
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
A target tracking scaling policy. Provides support for predefined or custom metrics.

The following predefined metrics are available:

  • ASGAverageCPUUtilization

  • ASGAverageNetworkIn

  • ASGAverageNetworkOut

  • ALBRequestCountPerTarget

If you specify ALBRequestCountPerTarget for the metric, you must specify the ResourceLabel property with the PredefinedMetricSpecification.

For more information, see TargetTrackingConfiguration in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference.

Required if the policy type is TargetTrackingScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.name: notificationTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.abstract: The type of event that causes the notification to be sent. To query the notification types supported by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling, call the DescribeAutoScalingNotificationTypes API.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.name: topicARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: defaultResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The action the Auto Scaling group takes when the lifecycle hook timeout elapses or if an unexpected failure occurs. The default value is ABANDON.

Valid values: CONTINUE | ABANDON

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: heartbeatTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract: The maximum time, in seconds, that can elapse before the lifecycle hook times out. The range is from 30 to 7200 seconds. The default value is 3600 seconds (1 hour).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: lifecycleTransition
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The lifecycle transition. For Auto Scaling groups, there are two major lifecycle transitions.

  • To create a lifecycle hook for scale-out events, specify autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCHING.

  • To create a lifecycle hook for scale-in events, specify autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATING.

Required for new lifecycle hooks, but optional when updating existing hooks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: notificationMetadata
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract: Additional information that you want to include any time Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends a message to the notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: notificationTargetARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the notification target that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling uses to notify you when an instance is in a wait state for the lifecycle hook. You can specify either an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue.

If you specify an empty string, this overrides the current ARN.

This operation uses the JSON format when sending notifications to an Amazon SQS queue, and an email key-value pair format when sending notifications to an Amazon SNS topic.

When you specify a notification target, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends it a test message. Test messages contain the following additional key-value pair: "Event": "autoscaling:TEST_NOTIFICATION".

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: roleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The ARN of the IAM role that allows the Auto Scaling group to publish to the specified notification target.

Valid only if the notification target is an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue. Required for new lifecycle hooks, but optional when updating existing hooks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.name: resourceLabel
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.abstract:
A label that uniquely identifies a specific Application Load Balancer target group from which to determine the average request count served by your Auto Scaling group. You can’t specify a resource label unless the target group is attached to the Auto Scaling group.

You create the resource label by appending the final portion of the load balancer ARN and the final portion of the target group ARN into a single value, separated by a forward slash (/). The format of the resource label is:

app/my-alb/778d41231b141a0f/targetgroup/my-alb-target-group/943f017f100becff.

Where:

  • app/<load-balancer-name>/<load-balancer-id> is the final portion of the load balancer ARN

  • targetgroup/<target-group-name>/<target-group-id> is the final portion of the target group ARN.

To find the ARN for an Application Load Balancer, use the DescribeLoadBalancers API operation. To find the ARN for the target group, use the DescribeTargetGroups API operation.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.name: predefinedMetricType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.abstract: Indicates which metrics to use. There are two different types of metrics for each metric type: one is a load metric and one is a scaling metric. For example, if the metric type is ASGCPUUtilization, the Auto Scaling group’s total CPU metric is used as the load metric, and the average CPU metric is used for the scaling metric.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.name: resourceLabel
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.abstract:
A label that uniquely identifies a specific Application Load Balancer target group from which to determine the total and average request count served by your Auto Scaling group. You can’t specify a resource label unless the target group is attached to the Auto Scaling group.

You create the resource label by appending the final portion of the load balancer ARN and the final portion of the target group ARN into a single value, separated by a forward slash (/). The format of the resource label is:

app/my-alb/778d41231b141a0f/targetgroup/my-alb-target-group/943f017f100becff.

Where:

  • app/<load-balancer-name>/<load-balancer-id> is the final portion of the load balancer ARN

  • targetgroup/<target-group-name>/<target-group-id> is the final portion of the target group ARN.

To find the ARN for an Application Load Balancer, use the DescribeLoadBalancers API operation. To find the ARN for the target group, use the DescribeTargetGroups API operation.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.name: resourceLabel
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingP.abstract:
A label that uniquely identifies a specific Application Load Balancer target group from which to determine the request count served by your Auto Scaling group. You can’t specify a resource label unless the target group is attached to the Auto Scaling group.

You create the resource label by appending the final portion of the load balancer ARN and the final portion of the target group ARN into a single value, separated by a forward slash (/). The format of the resource label is:

app/my-alb/778d41231b141a0f/targetgroup/my-alb-target-group/943f017f100becff.

Where:

  • app/<load-balancer-name>/<load-balancer-id> is the final portion of the load balancer ARN

  • targetgroup/<target-group-name>/<target-group-id> is the final portion of the target group ARN.

To find the ARN for an Application Load Balancer, use the DescribeLoadBalancers API operation. To find the ARN for the target group, use the DescribeTargetGroups API operation.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingM.name: predefinedMetricPairSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingM.abstract: The predefined metric pair specification from which Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling determines the appropriate scaling metric and load metric to use.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingM.name: targetValue
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingM.abstract:
Specifies the target utilization.

Some metrics are based on a count instead of a percentage, such as the request count for an Application Load Balancer or the number of messages in an SQS queue. If the scaling policy specifies one of these metrics, specify the target utilization as the optimal average request or message count per instance during any one-minute interval.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: metricDataQueries
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract: One or more metric data queries to provide the data points for a scaling metric. Use multiple metric data queries only if you are performing a math expression on returned data.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: metricDataQueries
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract: One or more metric data queries to provide the data points for a load metric. Use multiple metric data queries only if you are performing a math expression on returned data.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: metricDataQueries
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract: One or more metric data queries to provide the data points for a capacity metric. Use multiple metric data queries only if you are performing a math expression on returned data.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: maxCapacityBreachBehavior
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract:
Defines the behavior that should be applied if the forecast capacity approaches or exceeds the maximum capacity of the Auto Scaling group. Defaults to HonorMaxCapacity if not specified.

The following are possible values:

  • HonorMaxCapacity - Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling cannot scale out capacity higher than the maximum capacity. The maximum capacity is enforced as a hard limit.

  • IncreaseMaxCapacity - Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling can scale out capacity higher than the maximum capacity when the forecast capacity is close to or exceeds the maximum capacity. The upper limit is determined by the forecasted capacity and the value for MaxCapacityBuffer.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: maxCapacityBuffer
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract:
The size of the capacity buffer to use when the forecast capacity is close to or exceeds the maximum capacity. The value is specified as a percentage relative to the forecast capacity. For example, if the buffer is 10, this means a 10 percent buffer, such that if the forecast capacity is 50, and the maximum capacity is 40, then the effective maximum capacity is 55.

If set to 0, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling may scale capacity higher than the maximum capacity to equal but not exceed forecast capacity.

Required if the MaxCapacityBreachBehavior property is set to IncreaseMaxCapacity, and cannot be used otherwise.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: metricSpecifications
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract:
This structure includes the metrics and target utilization to use for predictive scaling.

This is an array, but we currently only support a single metric specification. That is, you can specify a target value and a single metric pair, or a target value and one scaling metric and one load metric.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: mode
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract: The predictive scaling mode. Defaults to ForecastOnly if not specified.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.name: schedulingBufferTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredictiveScalingC.abstract:
The amount of time, in seconds, by which the instance launch time can be advanced. For example, the forecast says to add capacity at 10:00 AM, and you choose to pre-launch instances by 5 minutes. In that case, the instances will be launched at 9:55 AM. The intention is to give resources time to be provisioned. It can take a few minutes to launch an EC2 instance. The actual amount of time required depends on several factors, such as the size of the instance and whether there are startup scripts to complete.

The value must be less than the forecast interval duration of 3600 seconds (60 minutes). Defaults to 300 seconds if not specified.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.name: predefinedMetricType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.abstract:
The metric type. The following predefined metrics are available:

  • ASGAverageCPUUtilization - Average CPU utilization of the Auto Scaling group.

  • ASGAverageNetworkIn - Average number of bytes received on all network interfaces by the Auto Scaling group.

  • ASGAverageNetworkOut - Average number of bytes sent out on all network interfaces by the Auto Scaling group.

  • ALBRequestCountPerTarget - Average Application Load Balancer request count per target for your Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.name: resourceLabel
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.abstract:
A label that uniquely identifies a specific Application Load Balancer target group from which to determine the average request count served by your Auto Scaling group. You can’t specify a resource label unless the target group is attached to the Auto Scaling group.

You create the resource label by appending the final portion of the load balancer ARN and the final portion of the target group ARN into a single value, separated by a forward slash (/). The format of the resource label is:

app/my-alb/778d41231b141a0f/targetgroup/my-alb-target-group/943f017f100becff.

Where:

  • app/<load-balancer-name>/<load-balancer-id> is the final portion of the load balancer ARN

  • targetgroup/<target-group-name>/<target-group-id> is the final portion of the target group ARN.

To find the ARN for an Application Load Balancer, use the DescribeLoadBalancers API operation. To find the ARN for the target group, use the DescribeTargetGroups API operation.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.name: alarms
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.abstract: The CloudWatch alarms created for the target tracking scaling policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.name: policyARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPoliciesType.html#.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPoliciesType.html#.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.name: topicARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon SNS topic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingNetworkBandwidthGb.name: max
Classes/AWSAutoScalingNetworkBandwidthGb.abstract: The maximum amount of network bandwidth, in gigabits per second (Gbps).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingNetworkBandwidthGb.name: min
Classes/AWSAutoScalingNetworkBandwidthGb.abstract: The minimum amount of network bandwidth, in gigabits per second (Gbps).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.name: launchTemplate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.abstract: One or more launch templates and the instance types (overrides) that are used to launch EC2 instances to fulfill On-Demand and Spot capacities.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricStat.html#/c.name: metric
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricStat.html#/c.abstract: The CloudWatch metric to return, including the metric name, namespace, and dimensions. To get the exact metric name, namespace, and dimensions, inspect the Metric object that is returned by a call to ListMetrics.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricStat.html#/c.name: stat
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricStat.html#/c.abstract:
The statistic to return. It can include any CloudWatch statistic or extended statistic. For a list of valid values, see the table in Statistics in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.

The most commonly used metrics for predictive scaling are Average and Sum.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricStat.html#/c.name: unit
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricStat.html#/c.abstract: The unit to use for the returned data points. For a complete list of the units that CloudWatch supports, see the MetricDatum data type in the Amazon CloudWatch API Reference.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricGranularityT.name: granularity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricGranularityT.abstract: The granularity. The only valid value is 1Minute.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.name: expression
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.abstract:
The math expression to perform on the returned data, if this object is performing a math expression. This expression can use the Id of the other metrics to refer to those metrics, and can also use the Id of other expressions to use the result of those expressions.

Conditional: Within each MetricDataQuery object, you must specify either Expression or MetricStat, but not both.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.name: identifier
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.abstract: A short name that identifies the object’s results in the response. This name must be unique among all MetricDataQuery objects specified for a single scaling policy. If you are performing math expressions on this set of data, this name represents that data and can serve as a variable in the mathematical expression. The valid characters are letters, numbers, and underscores. The first character must be a lowercase letter.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.name: label
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.abstract: A human-readable label for this metric or expression. This is especially useful if this is a math expression, so that you know what the value represents.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.name: metricStat
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.abstract:
Information about the metric data to return.

Conditional: Within each MetricDataQuery object, you must specify either Expression or MetricStat, but not both.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.name: returnData
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricDataQuery.ht.abstract:
Indicates whether to return the timestamps and raw data values of this metric.

If you use any math expressions, specify true for this value for only the final math expression that the metric specification is based on. You must specify false for ReturnData for all the other metrics and expressions used in the metric specification.

If you are only retrieving metrics and not performing any math expressions, do not specify anything for ReturnData. This sets it to its default (true).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetric.html#/c:obj.name: dimensions
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetric.html#/c:obj.abstract:
The dimensions for the metric. For the list of available dimensions, see the Amazon Web Services documentation available from the table in Amazon Web Services services that publish CloudWatch metrics in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.

Conditional: If you published your metric with dimensions, you must specify the same dimensions in your scaling policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetric.html#/c:obj.name: namespace
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetric.html#/c:obj.abstract: The namespace of the metric. For more information, see the table in Amazon Web Services services that publish CloudWatch metrics in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadForecast.html#.name: metricSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadForecast.html#.abstract: The metric specification for the load forecast.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadForecast.html#.name: timestamps
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadForecast.html#.abstract: The timestamps for the data points, in UTC format.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.name: loadBalancerTargetGroupARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the target group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.name: state
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.abstract:
The state of the target group.

  • Adding - The Auto Scaling instances are being registered with the target group.

  • Added - All Auto Scaling instances are registered with the target group.

  • InService - At least one Auto Scaling instance passed an ELB health check.

  • Removing - The Auto Scaling instances are being deregistered from the target group. If connection draining is enabled, Elastic Load Balancing waits for in-flight requests to complete before deregistering the instances.

  • Removed - All Auto Scaling instances are deregistered from the target group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState..name: state
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState..abstract:
One of the following load balancer states:

  • Adding - The Auto Scaling instances are being registered with the load balancer.

  • Added - All Auto Scaling instances are registered with the load balancer.

  • InService - At least one Auto Scaling instance passed an ELB health check.

  • Removing - The Auto Scaling instances are being deregistered from the load balancer. If connection draining is enabled, Elastic Load Balancing waits for in-flight requests to complete before deregistering the instances.

  • Removed - All Auto Scaling instances are deregistered from the load balancer.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: defaultResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract:
The action the Auto Scaling group takes when the lifecycle hook timeout elapses or if an unexpected failure occurs. The default value is ABANDON.

Valid values: CONTINUE | ABANDON

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: heartbeatTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: The maximum time, in seconds, that can elapse before the lifecycle hook times out. The range is from 30 to 7200 seconds. The default value is 3600 seconds (1 hour).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: lifecycleTransition
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract:
The lifecycle transition. For Auto Scaling groups, there are two major lifecycle transitions.

  • To create a lifecycle hook for scale-out events, specify autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCHING.

  • To create a lifecycle hook for scale-in events, specify autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATING.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: notificationMetadata
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: Additional information that you want to include any time Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends a message to the notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: notificationTargetARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the notification target that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends notifications to when an instance is in a wait state for the lifecycle hook. You can specify an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: roleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract:
The ARN of the IAM role that allows the Auto Scaling group to publish to the specified notification target. For information about creating this role, see Configure a notification target for a lifecycle hook in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Valid only if the notification target is an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group for the lifecycle hook.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: defaultResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract:
The action the Auto Scaling group takes when the lifecycle hook timeout elapses or if an unexpected failure occurs.

Valid values: CONTINUE | ABANDON

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: globalTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The maximum time, in seconds, that an instance can remain in a wait state. The maximum is 172800 seconds (48 hours) or 100 times HeartbeatTimeout, whichever is smaller.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: heartbeatTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The maximum time, in seconds, that can elapse before the lifecycle hook times out. If the lifecycle hook times out, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling performs the action that you specified in the DefaultResult property.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: notificationMetadata
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: Additional information that is included any time Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends a message to the notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: notificationTargetARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The ARN of the target that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends notifications to when an instance is in a wait state for the lifecycle hook.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: roleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The ARN of the IAM role that allows the Auto Scaling group to publish to the specified notification target (an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: launchTemplateId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract:
The ID of the launch template. To get the template ID, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeLaunchTemplates API operation. New launch templates can be created using the Amazon EC2 CreateLaunchTemplate API.

Conditional: You must specify either a LaunchTemplateId or a LaunchTemplateName.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: launchTemplateName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract:
The name of the launch template. To get the template name, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeLaunchTemplates API operation. New launch templates can be created using the Amazon EC2 CreateLaunchTemplate API.

Conditional: You must specify either a LaunchTemplateId or a LaunchTemplateName.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: version
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract: The version number, $Latest, or $Default. To get the version number, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeLaunchTemplateVersions API operation. New launch template versions can be created using the Amazon EC2 CreateLaunchTemplateVersion API. If the value is $Latest, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects the latest version of the launch template when launching instances. If the value is $Default, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects the default version of the launch template when launching instances. The default value is $Default.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: instanceRequirements
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
The instance requirements. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling uses your specified requirements to identify instance types. Then, it uses your On-Demand and Spot allocation strategies to launch instances from these instance types.

You can specify up to four separate sets of instance requirements per Auto Scaling group. This is useful for provisioning instances from different Amazon Machine Images (AMIs) in the same Auto Scaling group. To do this, create the AMIs and create a new launch template for each AMI. Then, create a compatible set of instance requirements for each launch template.

If you specify InstanceRequirements, you can’t specify InstanceType.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
The instance type, such as m3.xlarge. You must specify an instance type that is supported in your requested Region and Availability Zones. For more information, see Instance types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

You can specify up to 40 instance types per Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: launchTemplateSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
Provides a launch template for the specified instance type or set of instance requirements. For example, some instance types might require a launch template with a different AMI. If not provided, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling uses the launch template that’s specified in the LaunchTemplate definition. For more information, see Specifying a different launch template for an instance type in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

You can specify up to 20 launch templates per Auto Scaling group. The launch templates specified in the overrides and in the LaunchTemplate definition count towards this limit.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: weightedCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
If you provide a list of instance types to use, you can specify the number of capacity units provided by each instance type in terms of virtual CPUs, memory, storage, throughput, or other relative performance characteristic. When a Spot or On-Demand Instance is launched, the capacity units count toward the desired capacity. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches instances until the desired capacity is totally fulfilled, even if this results in an overage. For example, if there are two units remaining to fulfill capacity, and Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling can only launch an instance with a WeightedCapacity of five units, the instance is launched, and the desired capacity is exceeded by three units. For more information, see Configuring instance weighting for Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide. Value must be in the range of 1–999.

If you specify a value for WeightedCapacity for one instance type, you must specify a value for WeightedCapacity for all of them.

Every Auto Scaling group has three size parameters (DesiredCapacity, MaxSize, and MinSize). Usually, you set these sizes based on a specific number of instances. However, if you configure a mixed instances policy that defines weights for the instance types, you must specify these sizes with the same units that you use for weighting instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.name: overrides
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.abstract: Any properties that you specify override the same properties in the launch template.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurations
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The launch configurations.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The launch configuration names. If you omit this property, all launch configurations are described.

Array Members: Maximum number of 50 items.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: maxRecords
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The maximum number of items to return with this call. The default value is 50 and the maximum value is 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The token for the next set of items to return. (You received this token from a previous call.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The name of the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: associatePublicIpAddress
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: Specifies whether to assign a public IPv4 address to the group’s instances. If the instance is launched into a default subnet, the default is to assign a public IPv4 address, unless you disabled the option to assign a public IPv4 address on the subnet. If the instance is launched into a nondefault subnet, the default is not to assign a public IPv4 address, unless you enabled the option to assign a public IPv4 address on the subnet. For more information, see Launching Auto Scaling instances in a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: blockDeviceMappings
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The block device mapping entries that define the block devices to attach to the instances at launch. By default, the block devices specified in the block device mapping for the AMI are used. For more information, see Block Device Mapping in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: classicLinkVPCId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: Available for backward compatibility.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: classicLinkVPCSecurityGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: Available for backward compatibility.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: createdTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The creation date and time for the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: ebsOptimized
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: Specifies whether the launch configuration is optimized for EBS I/O (true) or not (false). For more information, see Amazon EBS-Optimized Instances in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: iamInstanceProfile
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The name or the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile associated with the IAM role for the instance. The instance profile contains the IAM role. For more information, see IAM role for applications that run on Amazon EC2 instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: imageId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The ID of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to use to launch your EC2 instances. For more information, see Find a Linux AMI in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: instanceMonitoring
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
Controls whether instances in this group are launched with detailed (true) or basic (false) monitoring.

For more information, see Configure Monitoring for Auto Scaling Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The instance type for the instances. For information about available instance types, see Available instance types in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: kernelId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The ID of the kernel associated with the AMI.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: keyName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The name of the key pair.

For more information, see Amazon EC2 Key Pairs in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The name of the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: metadataOptions
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The metadata options for the instances. For more information, see Configuring the Instance Metadata Options in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: placementTenancy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The tenancy of the instance, either default or dedicated. An instance with dedicated tenancy runs on isolated, single-tenant hardware and can only be launched into a VPC.

For more information, see Configuring instance tenancy with Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: ramdiskId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The ID of the RAM disk associated with the AMI.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: securityGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: A list that contains the security groups to assign to the instances in the Auto Scaling group. For more information, see Security Groups for Your VPC in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: spotPrice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The maximum hourly price to be paid for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request. Spot Instances are launched when the price you specify exceeds the current Spot price. For more information, see Requesting Spot Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: userData
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The user data to make available to the launched EC2 instances. For more information, see Instance metadata and user data (Linux) and Instance metadata and user data (Windows). If you are using a command line tool, base64-encoding is performed for you, and you can load the text from a file. Otherwise, you must provide base64-encoded text. User data is limited to 16 KB.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: onDemandAllocationStrategy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The allocation strategy to apply to your On-Demand Instances when they are launched. Possible instance types are determined by the launch template overrides that you specify.

The following lists the valid values:

lowest-price

Uses price to determine which instance types are the highest priority, launching the lowest priced instance types within an Availability Zone first. This is the default value for Auto Scaling groups that specify InstanceRequirements.

prioritized

You set the order of instance types for the launch template overrides from highest to lowest priority (from first to last in the list). Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches your highest priority instance types first. If all your On-Demand capacity cannot be fulfilled using your highest priority instance type, then Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches the remaining capacity using the second priority instance type, and so on. This is the default value for Auto Scaling groups that don’t specify InstanceRequirements and cannot be used for groups that do.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: onDemandBaseCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The minimum amount of the Auto Scaling group’s capacity that must be fulfilled by On-Demand Instances. This base portion is launched first as your group scales.

This number has the same unit of measurement as the group’s desired capacity. If you change the default unit of measurement (number of instances) by specifying weighted capacity values in your launch template overrides list, or by changing the default desired capacity type setting of the group, you must specify this number using the same unit of measurement.

Default: 0

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: onDemandPercentageAboveBaseCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
Controls the percentages of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances for your additional capacity beyond OnDemandBaseCapacity. Expressed as a number (for example, 20 specifies 20% On-Demand Instances, 80% Spot Instances). If set to 100, only On-Demand Instances are used.

Default: 100

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: spotAllocationStrategy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The allocation strategy to apply to your Spot Instances when they are launched. Possible instance types are determined by the launch template overrides that you specify.

The following lists the valid values:

capacity-optimized

Requests Spot Instances using pools that are optimally chosen based on the available Spot capacity. This strategy has the lowest risk of interruption. To give certain instance types a higher chance of launching first, use capacity-optimized-prioritized.

capacity-optimized-prioritized

You set the order of instance types for the launch template overrides from highest to lowest priority (from first to last in the list). Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling honors the instance type priorities on a best effort basis but optimizes for capacity first. Note that if the On-Demand allocation strategy is set to prioritized, the same priority is applied when fulfilling On-Demand capacity. This is not a valid value for Auto Scaling groups that specify InstanceRequirements.

lowest-price

Requests Spot Instances using the lowest priced pools within an Availability Zone, across the number of Spot pools that you specify for the SpotInstancePools property. To ensure that your desired capacity is met, you might receive Spot Instances from several pools. This is the default value, but it might lead to high interruption rates because this strategy only considers instance price and not available capacity.

price-capacity-optimized (recommended)

The price and capacity optimized allocation strategy looks at both price and capacity to select the Spot Instance pools that are the least likely to be interrupted and have the lowest possible price.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: spotInstancePools
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The number of Spot Instance pools across which to allocate your Spot Instances. The Spot pools are determined from the different instance types in the overrides. Valid only when the SpotAllocationStrategy is lowest-price. Value must be in the range of 1–20.

Default: 2

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: spotMaxPrice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance. If your maximum price is lower than the Spot price for the instance types that you selected, your Spot Instances are not launched. We do not recommend specifying a maximum price because it can lead to increased interruptions. When Spot Instances launch, you pay the current Spot price. To remove a maximum price that you previously set, include the property but specify an empty string (“”) for the value.

If you specify a maximum price, your instances will be interrupted more frequently than if you do not specify one.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 0.001

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceReusePolic.name: reuseOnScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceReusePolic.abstract: Specifies whether instances in the Auto Scaling group can be returned to the warm pool on scale in.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: acceleratorCount
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
The minimum and maximum number of accelerators (GPUs, FPGAs, or Amazon Web Services Inferentia chips) for an instance type.

To exclude accelerator-enabled instance types, set Max to 0.

Default: No minimum or maximum limits

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: acceleratorManufacturers
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Indicates whether instance types must have accelerators by specific manufacturers.

  • For instance types with NVIDIA devices, specify nvidia.

  • For instance types with AMD devices, specify amd.

  • For instance types with Amazon Web Services devices, specify amazon-web-services.

  • For instance types with Xilinx devices, specify xilinx.

Default: Any manufacturer

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: acceleratorNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Lists the accelerators that must be on an instance type.

  • For instance types with NVIDIA A100 GPUs, specify a100.

  • For instance types with NVIDIA V100 GPUs, specify v100.

  • For instance types with NVIDIA K80 GPUs, specify k80.

  • For instance types with NVIDIA T4 GPUs, specify t4.

  • For instance types with NVIDIA M60 GPUs, specify m60.

  • For instance types with AMD Radeon Pro V520 GPUs, specify radeon-pro-v520.

  • For instance types with Xilinx VU9P FPGAs, specify vu9p.

Default: Any accelerator

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: acceleratorTotalMemoryMiB
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
The minimum and maximum total memory size for the accelerators on an instance type, in MiB.

Default: No minimum or maximum limits

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: acceleratorTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Lists the accelerator types that must be on an instance type.

  • For instance types with GPU accelerators, specify gpu.

  • For instance types with FPGA accelerators, specify fpga.

  • For instance types with inference accelerators, specify inference.

Default: Any accelerator type

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: allowedInstanceTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
The instance types to apply your specified attributes against. All other instance types are ignored, even if they match your specified attributes.

You can use strings with one or more wild cards, represented by an asterisk (*), to allow an instance type, size, or generation. The following are examples: m5.8xlarge, c5*.*, m5a.*, r*, *3*.

For example, if you specify c5*, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will allow the entire C5 instance family, which includes all C5a and C5n instance types. If you specify m5a.*, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will allow all the M5a instance types, but not the M5n instance types.

If you specify AllowedInstanceTypes, you can’t specify ExcludedInstanceTypes.

Default: All instance types

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: bareMetal
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Indicates whether bare metal instance types are included, excluded, or required.

Default: excluded

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: baselineEbsBandwidthMbps
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
The minimum and maximum baseline bandwidth performance for an instance type, in Mbps. For more information, see Amazon EBS–optimized instances in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Default: No minimum or maximum limits

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: burstablePerformance
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Indicates whether burstable performance instance types are included, excluded, or required. For more information, see Burstable performance instances in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Default: excluded

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: cpuManufacturers
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Lists which specific CPU manufacturers to include.

  • For instance types with Intel CPUs, specify intel.

  • For instance types with AMD CPUs, specify amd.

  • For instance types with Amazon Web Services CPUs, specify amazon-web-services.

Don’t confuse the CPU hardware manufacturer with the CPU hardware architecture. Instances will be launched with a compatible CPU architecture based on the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) that you specify in your launch template.

Default: Any manufacturer

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: excludedInstanceTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
The instance types to exclude. You can use strings with one or more wild cards, represented by an asterisk (*), to exclude an instance family, type, size, or generation. The following are examples: m5.8xlarge, c5*.*, m5a.*, r*, *3*.

For example, if you specify c5*, you are excluding the entire C5 instance family, which includes all C5a and C5n instance types. If you specify m5a.*, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will exclude all the M5a instance types, but not the M5n instance types.

If you specify ExcludedInstanceTypes, you can’t specify AllowedInstanceTypes.

Default: No excluded instance types

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: instanceGenerations
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Indicates whether current or previous generation instance types are included.

  • For current generation instance types, specify current. The current generation includes EC2 instance types currently recommended for use. This typically includes the latest two to three generations in each instance family. For more information, see Instance types in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

  • For previous generation instance types, specify previous.

Default: Any current or previous generation

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: localStorage
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Indicates whether instance types with instance store volumes are included, excluded, or required. For more information, see Amazon EC2 instance store in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Default: included

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: localStorageTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
Indicates the type of local storage that is required.

  • For instance types with hard disk drive (HDD) storage, specify hdd.

  • For instance types with solid state drive (SSD) storage, specify ssd.

Default: Any local storage type

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.name: maxSpotPriceAsPercentageOfOptimalOnDemandPrice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
[Price protection] The price protection threshold for Spot Instances, as a percentage of an identified On-Demand price. The identified On-Demand price is the price of the lowest priced current generation C, M, or R instance type with your specified attributes. If no current generation C, M, or R instance type matches your attributes, then the identified price is from either the lowest priced current generation instance types or, failing that, the lowest priced previous generation instance types that match your attributes. When Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects instance types with your attributes, we will exclude instance types whose price exceeds your specified threshold.

The parameter accepts an integer, which Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling interprets as a percentage.

If you set DesiredCapacityType to vcpu or memory-mib, the price protection threshold is based on the per-vCPU or per-memory price instead of the per instance price.

Only one of SpotMaxPricePercentageOverLowestPrice or MaxSpotPriceAsPercentageOfOptimalOnDemandPrice can be specified. If you don’t specify either, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will automatically apply optimal price protection to consistently select from a wide range of instance types. To indicate no price protection threshold for Spot Instances, meaning you want to consider all instance types that match your attributes, include one of these parameters and specify a high value, such as 999999.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
[Price protection] The price protection threshold for On-Demand Instances, as a percentage higher than an identified On-Demand price. The identified On-Demand price is the price of the lowest priced current generation C, M, or R instance type with your specified attributes. If no current generation C, M, or R instance type matches your attributes, then the identified price is from either the lowest priced current generation instance types or, failing that, the lowest priced previous generation instance types that match your attributes. When Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects instance types with your attributes, we will exclude instance types whose price exceeds your specified threshold.

The parameter accepts an integer, which Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling interprets as a percentage.

To turn off price protection, specify a high value, such as 999999.

If you set DesiredCapacityType to vcpu or memory-mib, the price protection threshold is applied based on the per-vCPU or per-memory price instead of the per instance price.

Default: 20

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRequiremen.abstract:
[Price protection] The price protection threshold for Spot Instances, as a percentage higher than an identified Spot price. The identified Spot price is the price of the lowest priced current generation C, M, or R instance type with your specified attributes. If no current generation C, M, or R instance type matches your attributes, then the identified price is from either the lowest priced current generation instance types or, failing that, the lowest priced previous generation instance types that match your attributes. When Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects instance types with your attributes, we will exclude instance types whose price exceeds your specified threshold.

The parameter accepts an integer, which Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling interprets as a percentage.

If you set DesiredCapacityType to vcpu or memory-mib, the price protection threshold is based on the per-vCPU or per-memory price instead of the per instance price.

Only one of SpotMaxPricePercentageOverLowestPrice or MaxSpotPriceAsPercentageOfOptimalOnDemandPrice can be specified. If you don’t specify either, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will automatically apply optimal price protection to consistently select from a wide range of instance types. To indicate no price protection threshold for Spot Instances, meaning you want to consider all instance types that match your attributes, include one of these parameters and specify a high value, such as 999999.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefreshLiv.name: percentageComplete
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefreshLiv.abstract: The percentage of instances in the Auto Scaling group that have been replaced. For each instance replacement, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling tracks the instance’s health status and warm-up time. When the instance’s health status changes to healthy and the specified warm-up time passes, the instance is considered updated and is added to the percentage complete.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: desiredConfiguration
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: Describes the desired configuration for the instance refresh.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: endTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The date and time at which the instance refresh ended.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: instancesToUpdate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract:
The number of instances remaining to update before the instance refresh is complete.

If you roll back the instance refresh, InstancesToUpdate shows you the number of instances that were not yet updated by the instance refresh. Therefore, these instances don’t need to be replaced as part of the rollback.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: percentageComplete
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract:
The percentage of the instance refresh that is complete. For each instance replacement, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling tracks the instance’s health status and warm-up time. When the instance’s health status changes to healthy and the specified warm-up time passes, the instance is considered updated and is added to the percentage complete.

PercentageComplete does not include instances that are replaced during a rollback. This value gradually goes back down to zero during a rollback.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: progressDetails
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: Additional progress details for an Auto Scaling group that has a warm pool.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: startTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The date and time at which the instance refresh began.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: status
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract:
The current status for the instance refresh operation:

  • Pending - The request was created, but the instance refresh has not started.

  • InProgress - An instance refresh is in progress.

  • Successful - An instance refresh completed successfully.

  • Failed - An instance refresh failed to complete. You can troubleshoot using the status reason and the scaling activities.

  • Cancelling - An ongoing instance refresh is being cancelled.

  • Cancelled - The instance refresh is cancelled.

  • RollbackInProgress - An instance refresh is being rolled back.

  • RollbackFailed - The rollback failed to complete. You can troubleshoot using the status reason and the scaling activities.

  • RollbackSuccessful - The rollback completed successfully.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: statusReason

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMetadataOp.abstract:
This parameter enables or disables the HTTP metadata endpoint on your instances. If the parameter is not specified, the default state is enabled.

If you specify a value of disabled, you will not be able to access your instance metadata.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMetadataOp.name: httpPutResponseHopLimit
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMetadataOp.abstract:
The desired HTTP PUT response hop limit for instance metadata requests. The larger the number, the further instance metadata requests can travel.

Default: 1

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMetadataOp.name: httpTokens
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMetadataOp.abstract:
The state of token usage for your instance metadata requests. If the parameter is not specified in the request, the default state is optional.

If the state is optional, you can choose to retrieve instance metadata with or without a signed token header on your request. If you retrieve the IAM role credentials without a token, the version 1.0 role credentials are returned. If you retrieve the IAM role credentials using a valid signed token, the version 2.0 role credentials are returned.

If the state is required, you must send a signed token header with any instance metadata retrieval requests. In this state, retrieving the IAM role credentials always returns the version 2.0 credentials; the version 1.0 credentials are not available.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMaintenanc.name: maxHealthyPercentage
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMaintenanc.abstract:
Specifies the upper threshold as a percentage of the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group. It represents the maximum percentage of the group that can be in service and healthy, or pending, to support your workload when replacing instances. Value range is 100 to 200. To clear a previously set value, specify a value of -1.

Both MinHealthyPercentage and MaxHealthyPercentage must be specified, and the difference between them cannot be greater than 100. A large range increases the number of instances that can be replaced at the same time.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMaintenanc.name: minHealthyPercentage
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMaintenanc.abstract: Specifies the lower threshold as a percentage of the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group. It represents the minimum percentage of the group to keep in service, healthy, and ready to use to support your workload when replacing instances. Value range is 0 to 100. To clear a previously set value, specify a value of -1.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingGetPredictiveScali.abstract:
The exclusive end time of the time range for the forecast data to get. The maximum time duration between the start and end time is 30 days.

Although this parameter can accept a date and time that is more than two days in the future, the availability of forecast data has limits. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling only issues forecasts for periods of two days in advance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingGetPredictiveScali.name: startTime

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.name: name
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.abstract:
The name of the filter.

The valid values for Name depend on which API operation you’re using with the filter (DescribeAutoScalingGroups or DescribeTags).

DescribeAutoScalingGroups

Valid values for Name include the following:

  • tag-key - Accepts tag keys. The results only include information about the Auto Scaling groups associated with these tag keys.

  • tag-value - Accepts tag values. The results only include information about the Auto Scaling groups associated with these tag values.

  • tag:<key> - Accepts the key/value combination of the tag. Use the tag key in the filter name and the tag value as the filter value. The results only include information about the Auto Scaling groups associated with the specified key/value combination.

DescribeTags

Valid values for Name include the following:

  • auto-scaling-group - Accepts the names of Auto Scaling groups. The results only include information about the tags associated with these Auto Scaling groups.

  • key - Accepts tag keys. The results only include information about the tags associated with these tag keys.

  • value - Accepts tag values. The results only include information about the tags associated with these tag values.

  • propagate-at-launch - Accepts a Boolean value, which specifies whether tags propagate to instances at launch. The results only include information about the tags associated with the specified Boolean value.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.name: values
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.abstract:
One or more filter values. Filter values are case-sensitive.

If you specify multiple values for a filter, the values are automatically logically joined with an OR, and the request returns all results that match any of the specified values. For example, specify “tag:environment” for the filter name and “production,development” for the filter values to find Auto Scaling groups with the tag “environment=production” or “environment=development”.

The metric value to compare to BreachThreshold. This enables you to execute a policy of type StepScaling and determine which step adjustment to use. For example, if the breach threshold is 50 and you want to use a step adjustment with a lower bound of 0 and an upper bound of 10, you can set the metric value to 59.

If you specify a metric value that doesn’t correspond to a step adjustment for the policy, the call returns an error.

Required if the policy type is StepScaling and not supported otherwise.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: deleteOnTermination
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Indicates whether the volume is deleted on instance termination. For Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling, the default value is true.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: encrypted
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
Specifies whether the volume should be encrypted. Encrypted EBS volumes can only be attached to instances that support Amazon EBS encryption. For more information, see Supported instance types. If your AMI uses encrypted volumes, you can also only launch it on supported instance types.

If you are creating a volume from a snapshot, you cannot create an unencrypted volume from an encrypted snapshot. Also, you cannot specify a KMS key ID when using a launch configuration.

If you enable encryption by default, the EBS volumes that you create are always encrypted, either using the Amazon Web Services managed KMS key or a customer-managed KMS key, regardless of whether the snapshot was encrypted.

For more information, see Use Amazon Web Services KMS keys to encrypt Amazon EBS volumes in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: iops
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
The number of input/output (I/O) operations per second (IOPS) to provision for the volume. For gp3 and io1 volumes, this represents the number of IOPS that are provisioned for the volume. For gp2 volumes, this represents the baseline performance of the volume and the rate at which the volume accumulates I/O credits for bursting.

The following are the supported values for each volume type:

  • gp3: 3,000-16,000 IOPS

  • io1: 100-64,000 IOPS

For io1 volumes, we guarantee 64,000 IOPS only for Instances built on the Nitro System. Other instance families guarantee performance up to 32,000 IOPS.

Iops is supported when the volume type is gp3 or io1 and required only when the volume type is io1. (Not used with standard, gp2, st1, or sc1 volumes.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: snapshotId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:

You must specify either a VolumeSize or a SnapshotId.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The throughput (MiBps) to provision for a gp3 volume.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: volumeSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
The volume size, in GiBs. The following are the supported volumes sizes for each volume type:

  • gp2 and gp3: 1-16,384

  • io1: 4-16,384

  • st1 and sc1: 125-16,384

  • standard: 1-1,024

You must specify either a SnapshotId or a VolumeSize. If you specify both SnapshotId and VolumeSize, the volume size must be equal or greater than the size of the snapshot.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTrafficSou.abstract: The maximum number of items to return with this call. The maximum value is 50.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTrafficSou.name: trafficSourceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTrafficSou.abstract:
The traffic source type that you want to describe.

The following lists the valid values:

  • elb if the traffic source is a Classic Load Balancer.

  • elbv2 if the traffic source is a Application Load Balancer, Gateway Load Balancer, or Network Load Balancer.

  • vpc-lattice if the traffic source is VPC Lattice.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTerminatio.name: terminationPolicyTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTerminatio.abstract: The termination policies supported by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling: OldestInstance, OldestLaunchConfiguration, NewestInstance, ClosestToNextInstanceHour, Default, OldestLaunchTemplate, and AllocationStrategy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTagsType.h.name: filters
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTagsType.h.abstract: One or more filters to scope the tags to return. The maximum number of filters per filter type (for example, auto-scaling-group) is 1000.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeTagsType.h.name: maxRecords

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.name: endTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.abstract: The latest scheduled start time to return. If scheduled action names are provided, this property is ignored.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.name: maxRecords

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.name: scheduledActionNames

The names of one or more scheduled actions. If you omit this property, all scheduled actions are described. If you specify an unknown scheduled action, it is ignored with no error.

Array Members: Maximum number of 50 actions.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.name: startTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScheduledA.abstract: The earliest scheduled start time to return. If scheduled action names are provided, this property is ignored.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.name: activityIds
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.abstract:
The activity IDs of the desired scaling activities. If you omit this property, all activities for the past six weeks are described. If unknown activities are requested, they are ignored with no error. If you specify an Auto Scaling group, the results are limited to that group.

Array Members: Maximum number of 50 IDs.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.name: includeDeletedGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.abstract: Indicates whether to include scaling activity from deleted Auto Scaling groups.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.name: maxRecords

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeScalingAct.name: nextToken

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.name: maxRecords
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.abstract: The maximum number of items to be returned with each call. The default value is 50 and the maximum value is 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.name: nextToken

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.name: policyNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.abstract:
The names of one or more policies. If you omit this property, all policies are described. If a group name is provided, the results are limited to that group. If you specify an unknown policy name, it is ignored with no error.

Array Members: Maximum number of 50 items.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.name: policyTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribePoliciesTy.abstract: One or more policy types. The valid values are SimpleScaling, StepScaling, TargetTrackingScaling, and PredictiveScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeNotificati.name: autoScalingGroupNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeNotificati.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.name: nextToken

To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.name: maxRecords
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.abstract: The maximum number of items to return with this call. The default value is 100 and the maximum value is 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLoadBalanc.abstract: The token for the next set of items to return. (You received this token from a previous call.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLifecycleH.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLifecycleH.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLifecycleH.name: lifecycleHookNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLifecycleH.abstract: The names of one or more lifecycle hooks. If you omit this property, all lifecycle hooks are described.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLifecycleH.name: lifecycleHooks
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeLifecycleH.abstract: The lifecycle hooks for the specified group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeInstanceRe.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeInstanceRe.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeInstanceRe.abstract: The maximum number of items to return with this call. The default value is 50 and the maximum value is 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingDescribeInstanceRe.abstract: The token for the next set of items to return. (You received this token from a previous call.)
